text:
You reach the waterlogged shrine, a crumbled sanctum choked with vines and barnacles. Its central brazier, long extinguished, remains a monument to the faith drowned beneath these tides. As you draw near, the shrine pulses faintly, as though remembering warmth. With effort, you kindle it anew.

The flames rise with a hiss, steaming off the encroaching water and sending vapor spiraling into the fog. A fleeting vision flashes through the fire — a crowned figure weeping blood into the sea. Then nothing. The shrine grows still, but you feel lighter, your wounds soothed by the sacred flicker of remembrance.
lore: This shrine belonged to the Tidebound, a sect who believed fire could survive even in water — that faith could ignite even the drowned. Their teachings were banned as heresy. But the Flame remembers all who kneel to it, no matter how deep they fall.
